title: Management & Governance
description: Learn about AWS management tools, monitoring, and operational best practices

questions.question: What is AWS CloudFormation?
options: Infrastructure as Code service for provisioning resources using templates
questions.explanation: AWS CloudFormation allows you to model and provision AWS resources using templates (Infrastructure as Code).

questions.question: What is Amazon CloudWatch?
options: A monitoring and observability service for AWS resources and applications
questions.explanation: Amazon CloudWatch monitors AWS resources and applications, collecting and tracking metrics, logs, and events.

questions.question: What does AWS Systems Manager provide?
options: Operational insights and management capabilities for AWS resources
questions.explanation: AWS Systems Manager provides operational data, automates tasks, and helps manage EC2 instances and on-premises servers.

questions.question: What is AWS Config?
options: A service that tracks resource configurations and changes over time
questions.explanation: AWS Config continuously monitors and records AWS resource configurations and allows you to assess compliance.

questions.question: What is AWS CloudTrail used for?
options: Logging and monitoring API calls and account activity
questions.explanation: AWS CloudTrail logs API calls and account activity, providing audit trails for governance, compliance, and operational auditing.

questions.question: What is AWS Trusted Advisor?
options: A service providing real-time guidance on AWS best practices
questions.explanation: AWS Trusted Advisor provides real-time guidance to help you provision resources following AWS best practices.

questions.question: What are the five categories of Trusted Advisor checks?
options: Cost Optimization, Performance, Security, Fault Tolerance, Service Limits
questions.explanation: Trusted Advisor checks five categories: Cost Optimization, Performance, Security, Fault Tolerance, and Service Limits.

questions.question: What is AWS Organizations used for?
options: Centrally managing and governing multiple AWS accounts
questions.explanation: AWS Organizations helps you centrally manage and govern your environment as you scale AWS resources.

questions.question: What is AWS Service Catalog?
options: A list of all AWS services
A service to create and manage catalogs of approved IT services
questions.explanation: AWS Service Catalog allows organizations to create and manage catalogs of IT services approved for use on AWS.

questions.question: What is AWS Personal Health Dashboard?
options: A dashboard providing alerts and guidance when AWS events might affect your resources
questions.explanation: AWS Personal Health Dashboard provides alerts and remediation guidance when AWS events might impact your specific resources.

questions.question: What is AWS Control Tower?
options: A service to set up and govern a secure, multi-account AWS environment
questions.explanation: AWS Control Tower provides the easiest way to set up and govern a secure, multi-account AWS environment based on best practices.

questions.question: What is Amazon EventBridge?
options: A serverless event bus for connecting applications using events
questions.explanation: Amazon EventBridge is a serverless event bus that makes it easy to connect applications using data from your own apps, SaaS, and AWS services.

questions.question: What format does AWS CloudFormation use for templates?
questions.explanation: CloudFormation templates can be written in JSON or YAML format to define your AWS infrastructure as code.

questions.question: Which service helps you centrally manage multiple AWS accounts?
questions.explanation: AWS Organizations lets you centrally govern your environment as you grow and scale your AWS resources across multiple accounts.

questions.question: What does Amazon CloudWatch Logs do?
options: Collects and stores log files from AWS services and applications
questions.explanation: CloudWatch Logs enables you to centralize logs from all your systems, applications, and AWS services in a single service.

questions.question: What is AWS Service Catalog used for?
options: Creating and managing catalogs of approved IT services
questions.explanation: AWS Service Catalog allows organizations to create and manage catalogs of IT services that are approved for use on AWS.

questions.question: Which tool provides best practice recommendations for cost optimization, security, and performance?
questions.explanation: AWS Trusted Advisor checks your AWS environment and provides recommendations across five categories including cost, security, and performance.

questions.question: What does AWS Systems Manager Session Manager allow you to do?
options: Securely connect to EC2 instances without SSH keys or bastion hosts
questions.explanation: Session Manager provides secure and auditable instance management without needing to open inbound ports, maintain bastion hosts, or manage SSH keys.

questions.question: Which service enables you to set up and enforce guardrails for your multi-account environment?
questions.explanation: AWS Control Tower uses guardrails (preventive and detective) to enforce policies and detect policy violations in your multi-account environment.

questions.question: What can you use to track configuration changes to AWS resources over time?
questions.explanation: AWS Config continuously tracks configuration changes, allowing you to see what changed, who changed it, and when it was changed.

documentation:
Management & Governance

Infrastructure as Code:

  • AWS CloudFormation:
    • Define infrastructure using templates (JSON or YAML)
    • Version control your infrastructure
    • Automate resource provisioning
    • Create stacks from templates
    • Update and delete stacks as a single unit
    • No additional charge (pay for resources created)
  • AWS CDK (Cloud Development Kit):
    • Define infrastructure using programming languages
    • Supports TypeScript, Python, Java, C#
    • Synthesizes to CloudFormation templates

Monitoring and Observability:

  • Amazon CloudWatch:
    • Metrics: Monitor resource performance (CPU, disk, network)
    • Alarms: Automatically respond to changes (scale, notifications)
    • Logs: Centralized log storage and analysis
    • Events: Respond to state changes (now EventBridge)
    • Dashboards: Visualize metrics and logs
    • Insights: Analyze and visualize log data
  • AWS CloudTrail:
    • Records API calls and account activity
    • Who, what, when, where for AWS API calls
    • Stores logs in S3
    • Enables security analysis and compliance auditing
    • Can send to CloudWatch Logs
  • AWS X-Ray:
    • Analyzes and debugs distributed applications
    • Traces requests through your application
    • Identifies performance bottlenecks

Configuration and Compliance:

  • AWS Config:
    • Tracks resource configurations over time
    • Records configuration changes
    • Evaluates compliance with Config Rules
    • View configuration history
    • Send notifications when resources are non-compliant
  • AWS Systems Manager:
    • Session Manager: Secure shell access without SSH keys
    • Parameter Store: Store configuration data and secrets
    • Patch Manager: Automate patching
    • Run Command: Execute commands remotely
    • State Manager: Maintain consistent configuration
    • Inventory: Collect metadata from instances

Best Practice Guidance:

  • AWS Trusted Advisor:
    • Cost Optimization: Unused resources, idle instances
    • Performance: High utilization, throughput
    • Security: Security groups, IAM use, MFA
    • Fault Tolerance: Backups, multi-AZ, snapshots
    • Service Limits: Usage approaching limits
    • Basic support: 7 core checks
    • Business/Enterprise support: All checks
  • AWS Well-Architected Tool:
    • Review workloads against best practices
    • Based on Well-Architected Framework
    • Free to use
    • Generates improvement plan

Multi-Account Management:

  • AWS Organizations:
    • Centrally manage multiple AWS accounts
    • Consolidated billing
    • Hierarchical account structure (OUs)
    • Service Control Policies (SCPs): Central access control
    • Automate account creation
    • Free service
  • AWS Control Tower:
    • Set up multi-account environment with best practices
    • Built on AWS Organizations
    • Guardrails for governance
    • Account Factory for provisioning
    • Dashboard for visibility

Service Management:

  • AWS Service Catalog:
    • Create and manage approved IT service catalogs
    • Centrally manage commonly deployed services
    • Enforce standards and compliance
    • Users can self-service provision
  • AWS License Manager:
    • Manage licenses from vendors (Microsoft, Oracle, SAP)
    • Set licensing rules
    • Track license usage

Automation and Operations:

  • AWS OpsWorks:
    • Configuration management using Chef or Puppet
    • Automate server configuration
    • Deploy applications
  • Amazon EventBridge:
    • Serverless event bus
    • Connect applications using events
    • Event patterns and scheduled events
    • Route events to Lambda, SNS, SQS, etc.

Health and Support:

  • AWS Personal Health Dashboard:
    • Personalized view of AWS service health
    • Alerts when AWS events affect your resources
    • Proactive notifications
    • Remediation guidance
  • AWS Service Health Dashboard:
    • General status of AWS services
    • Public view of service availability
    • Historical information

Tags and Resource Groups:

  • Tags:
    • Key-value pairs for organizing resources
    • Track costs by project, department, environment
    • Enforce tagging policies
    • Automate operations based on tags
  • Resource Groups:
    • Organize resources by tags
    • Manage and automate tasks on multiple resources
    • View and manage grouped resources

Deployment and Change Management:

  • AWS CodePipeline: CI/CD service
  • AWS CodeDeploy: Automated deployments
  • AWS CodeBuild: Build and test code
  • AWS CodeCommit: Git repositories

Management Best Practices:

  1. Use Infrastructure as Code for consistency
  2. Enable comprehensive monitoring and logging
  3. Implement automation to reduce manual work
  4. Use tags consistently for organization
  5. Set up CloudTrail for audit trails
  6. Regular reviews with Trusted Advisor
  7. Use AWS Organizations for multi-account strategy
  8. Implement alerts for critical events
